CAMS tracks and forecasts greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane by combining data from satellites and in-situ measurements with computer modeling to simulate concentrations of the two greenhouse gases based on its knowledge of the atmosphere, biosphere, and reported emissions. By comparing observations and simulations, scientists from CAMS can spot where the two do not match, enabling the service to improve its knowledge and estimates of the natural sources and sinks of greenhouse gases. CAMS also uses observations from both satellites and ground-based measurement stations to monitor atmospheric methane concentrations. Additionally, CAMS uses computer models of the atmosphere to estimate the strength of various emission sources over time.

CAMS (Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service) plays a crucial role in monitoring SO₂ emissions from volcanic eruptions. CAMS combines satellite and non-satellite observations with a numerical weather prediction model and air quality models to provide daily forecasts of the composition of the air worldwide. Specifically, CAMS monitors the atmospheric impacts of SO₂ from volcanic eruptions, providing data on the transport and chemical evolution of SO₂ as it is transported away from the volcano. CAMS also provides information on the conversion of SO₂ into sulphate aerosol, which can contribute to increased levels of fine particulate matter (e.g. PM2.5), leading to a reduction in air quality. Additionally, CAMS uses satellite data to estimate the emission rates and altitudes of volcanic eruptions, and to track the transport of SO₂ plumes.

CAMS supports new applications through its Use Cases projects, which aim to stimulate innovative ideas and support the development of downstream applications. The goal of these projects is to bring about success stories of uptake of CAMS products and to spin-up sustainable businesses. The Use Cases projects are selected based on criteria such as the innovative use of one or more CAMS products, the sustainability of the Application business plan, the potential for increasing the use of CAMS services, and the quality and value for money of the bids.

The main goal of the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) is to support adaptation and mitigation policies of the European Union by providing consistent and authoritative information about climate change. Additionally, C3S aims to provide free and open access to climate data and tools based on the best available science, and to help users deal with the consequences of climate change and prepare for the future through mitigation and adaptation.

C3S users include scientists, consultants, planners, and policymakers, the media, and the public. They use C3S data and tools for various purposes, such as assessing climate change impacts on biodiversity, risk management for commodity trading, and sustainable water management. Additionally, C3S data is used in the energy industry, for example, by companies like Vortex, which uses C3S data to provide information on wind resources for wind farm operators. C3S also provides data and tools for renewable energy production, such as solar radiation data from CAMS, which is used by companies like NOVELTIS to support the installation of solar panels.

The Climate Data Store (CDS) is a one-stop shop for information about the climate: past, present, and future. It provides easy access to a wide range of climate datasets via a searchable catalogue. The CDS helps the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) with its mission by providing a central and holistic view of all information available to the C3S, consistent and seamless access to existing data repositories distributed over multiple data suppliers, a catalogue of all data and products available, quality information on all data and products, and access to a software toolbox that allows users to perform computations on the data and products.

C3S ensures its climate data is accurate and reliable through a quality assurance framework that includes evaluating the quality of datasets, providing information on data quality, and making data traceable and reproducible. The service also invests in quality assurance activities, such as supporting investigations into evaluating the quality of observations, seasonal forecasts, and climate projections. Additionally, C3S provides information on the quality of each dataset, including advice on how the data can be used, and includes quality assessment information in the Climate Data Store.
The European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) implements the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) on behalf of the European Union.

C3S supports the European Union's climate adaptation and mitigation efforts by providing authoritative information about the past, present, and future climate in Europe and the rest of the world. The service offers free and open access to climate data and tools based on the best available science, which helps policymakers, businesses, and citizens understand and adapt to the effects of climate change. C3S also provides climate data and information on impacts on a range of topics and sectoral areas through the Climate Data Store (CDS), which enables users to tailor services to more specific public or commercial needs. Additionally, C3S supports the development of national and local climate adaptation strategies by providing consistent datasets covering all EEA Member States, ensuring that they are all able to adapt to climate change.

C3S offers various types of tenders and contracts to support its work, including Quality Assurance tenders, Content creation tenders, Communication Services tenders, Operational Service tenders, Sectoral Information System (SIS) tenders, Demo Case contracts, Use Case contracts, and National Collaboration Programme (NCP) tenders.

C3S engages with users and stakeholders through various means to understand their needs and offer relevant services. One way is through user workshops, such as the C3S User engagement Workshop with the Belgian user community, which provides a platform for users to learn about C3S services, meet the C3S team, and exchange information about their potential interest and requirements. Additionally, C3S offers technical support and training to users of the Climate Data Store (CDS), combining online learning with face-to-face events in most countries across Europe. C3S also organizes General Assemblies, which bring together users, data providers, and other stakeholders to share experiences, discuss user requirements, and brainstorm on how to improve and move the service forward. Furthermore, C3S has a User Consultation workshop to establish a long-term picture of the requirements for Copernicus services and to indicate the relationships of C3S to the other Copernicus services.

C3S (Copernicus Climate Change Service) works closely with other Copernicus services, including the Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). They frequently collaborate because the subjects of climate change and atmosphere monitoring are inextricably linked. Both services are currently working together on a project to monitor anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions on a range of scales, from local to global. Additionally, C3S and CAMS have worked together on COVID-19 research.

C3S supports climate services and the use of climate data in policies and standards by providing consistent and authoritative information about the past, present, and future climate in Europe and the rest of the world. The service offers free and open access to climate data and tools based on the best available science, which is used by policymakers, researchers, and the public to make informed decisions regarding climate change mitigation and adaptation. C3S data allow scientists and policymakers to track indicators such as temperature changes, sea level rise, and melting ice caps, which is invaluable for assessing the impact of climate change, formulating evidence-based policies, and developing effective mitigation and adaptation strategies. The tools and products produced by C3S support policymakers in understanding the effects of climate change on a range of areas, including urban infrastructure, energy demand, tourism, and biodiversity.
The main goal of ECMWF's Medium-Range Flood Forecasting System is to produce flood warnings based on Medium Range Weather Forecasts.

The system uses medium-range weather forecasts to predict floods by employing downscaling techniques to produce reliable flood warnings beyond the current flood warning period of approximately 3 days. The system is designed to incorporate both detailed models for specific basins as well as a broad scale for entire Europe, allowing for the use of different rainfall-runoff flood models linked to the Medium-Range Weather Forecasts to provide Medium Range Flood Forecasts. The system also investigates the concept of an overall water balance hydrological model as a basis for regional rainfall-runoff flood modelling.

The system handles uncertainties in weather and water models by using ensembles and combining outputs from several models, independently developed, initialised and operated. This approach allows for the quantification of uncertainties arising from imperfect knowledge of the initial conditions of the components of the Earth system and approximations made in the models. Additionally, the system uses climate models that include representations of the atmosphere, ocean, and land surface to predict the evolution of the state of the system in time.

The European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) plays a crucial role in the flood forecasting system by providing added value early flood forecasting products to hydrological services and unique overview products of ongoing and forecasted floods in Europe more than 3 days in advance. EFAS contributes to better protection of the European citizen, the environment, property, and cultural heritage.

The system combines detailed local models with a broad view across Europe by using a multi-system seasonal forecast service, where data produced by state-of-the-art seasonal forecast systems developed, implemented and operated at forecast centres in several European countries is collected, processed and combined to enable user-relevant applications. Additionally, it uses an ensemble of different atmospheric models with the same boundary conditions to optimise forecasts and estimate uncertainties, enhancing local detail while considering the broader European context. Regional models covering European territory have a higher 10 km spatial resolution, allowing for more detailed local forecasts, which take their ‘boundary conditions’ from a global model, tracking masses of air flowing in and out, and making greater use of surface air quality observations.

The resolution of the hydrological model used in the flood forecasting system varies depending on the specific model and version. For the LISFLOOD hydrological model used in the EFAS system, the resolution is 1x1 arcminute (~1.5 km at EFAS latitudes). For version 4.0, the resolution is 5x5 km. For the GloFAS system, the resolution is 0.1° (~11 km at the equator) for version 3.1 and older.

The system uses seasonal weather forecasts to predict river flow and water levels over seasons by forcing hydrological models with seasonal meteorological ensemble forecasts. For example, the European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) uses the LISFLOOD hydrological model at a 1x1 arcminute resolution (~1.5 km at EFAS latitudes) with seasonal meteorological ensemble forecasts from the European Centre of Medium-range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). The forecasts are initialised on the first of each month with a lead time of 215 days at 24-hour time steps.

ECMWF's research in seasonal forecasting helps improve sea level predictions through the assimilation of conventional and satellite observations, particularly radar altimeter sea-level anomaly (SLA) data. This data assimilation improves the representation of the seasonal and inter-annual variability of sea level, which is important for extended-range and seasonal-range weather forecasts. By incorporating this data into their ocean data assimilation system, ECMWF can produce more accurate predictions of sea level changes, which is crucial for understanding and predicting climate variability, such as El Niño events.

ECMWF's research in atmospheric composition data helps improve CAMS and C3S by providing high-quality data that can be used to create datasets describing and predicting different properties of the Earth's atmosphere and climate. This data is used to support public and private entities in demonstrating how data can be processed, and to create useful applications such as providing information on climate variability to help the renewable energy sector decide where to put wind farms, and helping citizens with respiratory problems monitor levels of air pollution when they travel. Additionally, ECMWF's research helps improve CAMS by providing daily atmospheric composition forecasts on regional and global scales, and by setting up new partnerships with entities across Europe to continue to provide all CAMS services. ECMWF's research also helps improve C3S by producing temperature maps and charts detailing the average global and European air temperatures, and by launching ERA5, the most powerful atmosphere reanalysis tool, which enables users to look back in time on the weather for the past 40 years.

ECMWF's Summer of Weather Code (ESoWC) is an innovation programme run by ECMWF and Copernicus, which aims to bring together teams to solve technical challenges and to work on innovative open-source software solutions related to weather, climate, and atmosphere. Through ESoWC, developer teams pair up with experienced mentors at ECMWF and Copernicus to work on cutting-edge open-source software developments during a four-month coding phase. The programme helps create better weather forecasting tools by providing a platform for developers to work on innovative solutions, such as machine learning applications, visualisation projects, and data compression.
ECMWF's research on emissions helps improve air quality forecasts and climate models for CAMS by providing a better understanding of the factors that impact air quality.

ECMWF's research in user experience helps make CAMS and C3S websites more user-friendly through a research project that evaluates new designs for the service websites. The project involves gathering feedback from users to identify areas for improvement and make recommendations for enhancing the user experience. This feedback is used to inform the development of the websites, ensuring that they are more intuitive and easier to use for a wider range of users.

ECMWF faces challenges in evaluating the impact of its research on the Copernicus program, particularly in terms of ensuring that its users can benefit from the ever-growing volumes of data produced. To address this challenge, ECMWF is working with Mercator Ocean and EUMETSAT to implement a cloud-based platform, known as the Data Information Access Service (DIAS), which will allow users to run their own algorithms "next to the data" and access data from the three organizations seamlessly. Additionally, ECMWF is using machine learning to improve its data assimilation processes and make its data more usable for users. Furthermore, ECMWF is addressing the challenge of evaluating the impact of its research by developing user-driven applications that make climate data accessible and relevant to specific sectors, such as water management, agriculture, and energy. Additionally, ECMWF is working to provide climate indicators that can be used to help build resilient cities and mitigate the challenges posed by climate change.

ECMWF's research in reanalysis improves climate modeling and weather forecasting by providing a comprehensive and consistent representation of the Earth's climate system. Reanalysis combines past weather observations with advanced computer models to reconstruct past weather conditions, filling gaps in observations and providing a seamless panorama of the past climate. This allows for the evaluation of the evolution of the climate and serves as a starting point for making projections about the future. The use of reanalysis in climate modeling and weather forecasting introduces the laws of physics into the data, providing the fundamental elements of how different parts of the atmosphere and climate system interact. This has led to the development of more accurate and reliable reanalysis datasets, which are used to improve climate modeling and weather forecasting.

ECMWF plays a crucial role in working with other countries to improve weather forecasting and climate prediction. As an independent intergovernmental organisation, ECMWF is supported by 34 states and works closely with various international partners, including the European Meteorological Infrastructure (EMI), the World Meteorological Organisation, the European Union, and the European Space Agency. The organisation also works with the Copernicus programme, which is the European Union's flagship Earth observation programme, to deliver operational data and services related to the Earth's environment. In addition, ECMWF has expanded its location across its Member States for some activities, including new offices in Bonn, Germany, which focus on activities conducted in partnership with the EU, such as Copernicus. This highlights ECMWF's commitment to working with other countries to advance weather forecasting and climate prediction.

ECMWF, ESA, and EUMETSAT collaborate on various aspects of the Copernicus programme, including the development of the space segment, the operation of satellites, and the delivery of data. Specifically, ECMWF implements the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) on behalf of the European Commission. ESA is responsible for the development of the space segment of the programme, while EUMETSAT operates the Sentinel-3 satellites and delivers the marine mission. Additionally, ECMWF, ESA, and EUMETSAT work together on initiatives such as the monitoring of anthropogenic CO2 emissions.

The agreement between ECMWF and the Union for the Mediterranean (UfM) is about establishing bilateral cooperation concerning the uptake and impact of EU Copernicus services implemented by ECMWF. The UfM pledges to maximize the uptake of the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS), while ECMWF is to ensure that relevant expertise is made available. The agreement aims to support the Mediterranean countries and regional partners in their efforts to address the challenges of climate change.

ECMWF cooperates with Mercator Ocean to provide ocean data and support the Copernicus Marine Service through various projects and discussions. ECMWF works with Mercator Ocean to deliver ocean analysis following a call for tender. Additionally, ECMWF contributed to the first issue of the 'OCEAN STATE REPORT' of the Copernicus Marine Service, coordinated by Mercator Ocean. The Copernicus Marine Service delivers data to ECMWF, such as sea-surface temperature, ocean sea ice, and sea-level observations, which are used for ECMWF's operational ocean data assimilation. Furthermore, Mercator Ocean and ECMWF are partners in the ATLANTOS H2020 project, which aims to improve international collaboration in the design, implementation, and benefit sharing of the ocean observing system.

The Data Information Access Service (DIAS) project is a cloud-based platform that allows users to access and process large volumes of data from ECMWF, EUMETSAT, and Mercator Ocean. This project enables the three partners to work together by providing a common platform for data access and processing, thus facilitating the use of Copernicus data and avoiding redundancy between the Copernicus Services. The collaboration allows the partners to address the challenge of managing large volumes of data and providing users with easy and secure access to essential satellite and related data. Additionally, the project enables the integration of data from external partners without the need for structural adaptations.

ECMWF works closely with the European Commission on the Copernicus Programme, implementing two of its services: the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). These services play a key role in supporting the EU's climate change mitigation and adaptation policies, as part of the European Green Deal. The collaboration is based on a Contribution Agreement signed in July 2021.

ECMWF's international cooperation plays a crucial role in developing new weather forecasting products and encouraging innovation. By partnering with organizations such as the European Meteorological Infrastructure (EMI), the World Meteorological Organisation, the European Union, and the European Space Agency, ECMWF can leverage expertise and resources, leading to the development of new products and services. For instance, ECMWF's cooperation with the European Union and the European Space Agency has facilitated the development of the Copernicus programme, which provides freely accessible operational data and services related to environmental issues. Additionally, the integration of machine learning into ECMWF's modelling and predictions, facilitated through partnerships, has improved the accuracy and reliability of weather forecasts.

ECMWF's international work helps achieve the European Green Deal's goals, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030, through its Copernicus services for Climate Change and Atmosphere Monitoring. These services provide quality-assured and freely accessible environmental data, which supports the EU's target plan to further reduce net greenhouse emissions by at least 55% until 2030.

Organize user feedback loops via user workshops. Set up and maintain the CAMS User Requirements Data Base (URDB) that keeps a record of all user requirements and their analysis.

ECMWF ensures users get the most out of its products and are satisfied through various means. Firstly, it provides a range of channels for getting the necessary help and support, including a 24/7 Knowledge Base, a Forum, and a Contact us option. Additionally, ECMWF conducts user satisfaction surveys to collect feedback and improve its services. Furthermore, it offers training to its users through workshops and online resources. Additionally, it has a Quality Assurance process in place to continually check the accuracy of its products against independent observations.

The User Advisory Board (UAB) plays a crucial role in improving C3S services and involving tourism experts. It provides feedback on the fitness for purpose of the solution being developed, the nature of the service delivery, and broadens its use. The UAB involves tourism experts and organizations with advanced knowledge of the climate change impacts on the tourism sector, who can speak on behalf of different types of users. The UAB has held several meetings during the system design and service development stages, providing recommendations on the ongoing development and final recommendations after the second delivery. This sectoral and user-centered board can be proposed as a long-term mechanism in support of the Evaluation and Quality Control (EQC) component of C3S.

ECMWF collaborates with other organisations to organise workshops for its data users, where users become acquainted with Copernicus products and data, meet members of the CAMS and C3S teams, and provide feedback to Copernicus scientists on how data and products could be improved.

The National Collaboration Programme (NCP) in the Copernicus Marine Service is a programme that aims to boost user adoption and satisfaction while unlocking new possibilities for data and product applications. The NCP seeks to enhance interaction and cooperation with core users at the national level to better support marine policy and governance stakeholders in EU Member States and EU Contributing States. The programme fosters a collaborative environment to facilitate the uptake of Copernicus Marine data and products in user-focused services and applications supporting healthy ocean and sustainable blue economy. By doing so, the NCP increases user adoption by providing a platform for users to share their experiences, needs, and requirements, and for the Copernicus Marine Service to respond to these needs and improve its services.

ECMWF uses user engagement to boost satisfaction, encourage new uses of data, and offer training for the Climate Data Store (CDS) through surveys, workshops, training activities, hackathons, and technical support.

The purpose of the C3S User Engagement Workshop with the Belgian community is to provide a unique opportunity for interested Belgian individuals and organisations to learn about C3S services and how they can benefit their activities, meet members of the C3S team, and exchange information about their potential interest and requirements towards the use and application of C3S data and services.

ECMWF works with national climate services and academic communities to improve C3S by involving them in the implementation of C3S and deriving maximum benefit from the existing infrastructure and knowledge. This collaboration allows C3S to complement the established range of meteorological and environmental services that each European country already has in place. Additionally, ECMWF also organizes meetings and workshops, including the annual General Assemblies, which allow members of the climate change community to join networking and brainstorming sessions to contribute to future developments of C3S.

The User Intelligence and Uptake sessions in the C3S NCP are part of the Copernicus Climate Change Service's (C3S) efforts to enhance user engagement and uptake of its products and services. The sessions aim to collect user requirements and intelligence, which are then used to support the strategy and evolution of the C3S. The User Intelligence and Uptake sessions are designed to increase user uptake and user satisfaction, promote the development of novel ways of using the data, and provide training to enhance the overall impact of the Copernicus services.

ECMWF ensures its user engagement is based on real needs by conducting various stakeholder consultations, user workshops, and gathering user requirements through the CAMS User Requirements Data Base (URDB). This information is used to inform the development of services and products, ensuring they meet the needs of users.

ECMWF helps health workers understand the effects of climate change on health through the Copernicus Health Hub, which gathers all the products, datasets, and information generated by the six Copernicus Services that can serve health professionals, policymakers, or researchers in the field of health. The Copernicus Health Hub maps the products generated by all six Copernicus services and other European initiatives, like Destination Earth, and facilitates access to this data, supporting users working in the area of physical, mental health, and wellbeing. By providing this information, the Copernicus Health Hub helps health workers understand the impacts of climate change on health and make informed decisions.

The Copernicus Health Hub is a platform that gathers information from the six Copernicus Services and the Copernicus Space Component to support users working on physical health, mental health, and well-being. It provides a comprehensive range of cross-cutting data and products, aiming to bridge the gap between the environmental and health communities. The Hub offers information on diseases and epidemics, as well as on green spaces and adapting cities to a changing climate, which can affect human health. It is useful for policymakers on climate and health as it provides access to documentation, catalogues, inspirational use case stories, and other resources, facilitating the gathering of feedback and new user requirements from the health sector, which can directly feed the evolution of the Copernicus Services. The Hub's data and tools can be used for various purposes, such as informing policy-makers about environmental risks and supporting the development of health-related applications for the general public.

Climate change has a significant impact on human health, and the biggest health risks from extreme weather include heat-related illnesses, respiratory problems, and the spread of infectious diseases. Heatwaves, in particular, are a major concern, as they can cause heat stress, which increases the risk of death from heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Additionally, climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of heatwaves, extreme precipitation events, and droughts, which can lead to a range of health problems, including cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.
The European Health Service, as a part of C3S, provides users with tailor-made climate information for the health domain.

ECMWF uses Earth observation data to create products that help the health sector by providing information on environmental drivers such as temperature, humidity, air quality, UV radiation, and evolution of habitats for disease vectors. The Copernicus Health Hub, launched by ECMWF, is a platform that gathers information from the six Copernicus Services and the Copernicus Space Component to support users working on physical health, mental health, and well-being.

The challenges in adapting to health risks from climate change include the lack of information and knowledge within the health care sector regarding climate-related disease patterns. Climate change is rarely addressed in both education of health professionals and the training of practicing medical and public health staff, which affects the development of preventative health strategies. Additionally, the healthcare sector is already at the forefront of treating climate change impacts, and nurses face time constraints, lack of knowledge on the topic of health impacts of climate change, and lack of leadership capacity as limiting factors for the development of their skills and the evolution of their daily practices in a changing climate.

The Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), implemented by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), provides health-related climate information through various tools and applications, such as the Monthly Climate Explorer for COVID-19, which allows users to explore the connections between temperature, humidity, and COVID-19 mortality rates. Recent research has found that outbreaks of viral diseases often show a marked seasonal cycle, and the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 occurred in regions characterized by average temperatures of 5–11°C and a specific humidity of 3–6 g/kg. C3S provides historic, current, and future data on temperature and humidity up to a resolution of 12 kilometers over land, which can be used by researchers to test the climate determinants hypothesis and explore the claims that temperature and humidity could affect the spread of COVID-19.

Heatwaves in Europe are important because they can have severe impacts on human health, particularly for vulnerable populations such as the elderly, infants, and those with pre-existing medical conditions. Climate services can play a crucial role in developing heat health action plans by providing accurate and timely weather forecasts, which can be used to trigger heatwave alerts and warnings. Climate services can also help identify areas that are most vulnerable to heatwaves, allowing for targeted interventions and resource allocation. Additionally, climate services can provide information on the expected impacts of heatwaves on human health, which can be used to inform heat health action plans and develop effective response strategies.

CAMS provides daily analyses and forecasts of worldwide long-range transport of atmospheric pollutants as well as the background air quality for the European domain. This data is used to provide daily forecasts of the composition of the air worldwide, which can be used to assess the impact of air pollution on human health. Exposure to poor air quality can lead to a significantly reduced lifespan, as well as presenting health complications ranging from irritation of the eyes, nose and throat to acute and chronic respiratory disease, heart disease and stroke.

The main health challenges from climate change include increased disease prevalence, more frequent extreme weather events, heatwaves, air pollution, vector-borne diseases, and mental health impacts. Climate change also has a negative impact on all determinants of health, further increasing the prevalence of infectious and vector-borne diseases, and heightening the risk of extreme weather events.

ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts) implements the Copernicus Programme as part of its services, operating the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) and the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S). ECMWF also contributes to the Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS), which is implemented by the EU Joint Research Council (JRC). ECMWF's role in the Copernicus Programme helps with Earth observation by providing freely accessible operational data and services, which deliver reliable and up-to-date information related to the planet and its environment. These data and services support a wide range of applications, including climate monitoring, air quality monitoring, and emergency management.

CAMS tracks and predicts air quality by combining information obtained from satellite and ground-based observations with detailed computer models of the atmosphere. The service uses a multi-model approach, operating an ensemble of eleven top-tier models that produce daily operational gridded forecasts using advanced chemistry-transport models (CTM). CAMS also uses an AI approach, making use of observations from air quality monitoring networks set-up by countries across Europe, to provide more accurate forecasts of regulated pollutants.

The Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) is implemented by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) as part of The Copernicus Programme. ECMWF runs C3S on behalf of the European Commission.

ECMWF uses Earth observation data to show climate change and its effects through its Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). These services provide freely accessible operational data and information services, which provide users with reliable and up-to-date information related to environmental issues. The data is used to generate reanalysis datasets, which are complete and consistent representations of climate and atmospheric composition across time. This is achieved by merging numerical computer models of the atmosphere with existing real-world observations recorded over the course of decades. The reanalysis datasets are used to provide a clear picture of changes in climate and atmospheric composition, which is important in helping society adapt to Earth's continually evolving environment. The data is also used to support the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and to monitor the effectiveness of the COP21 Paris Agreement.

The Global Land and Marine Observations Database is implemented by ECMWF as part of The Copernicus Programme. It provides a centralized repository of historical surface meteorological data, which can be used to improve the accuracy of weather forecasts and climate models. The database supports the development of climate products and services, such as the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).

ECMWF collaborates with other organizations, such as Mercator Ocean, to improve Earth observation and climate research. This collaboration is evident in joint projects like the ATLANTOS H2020 project, where ECMWF and Mercator Ocean aim to develop a fully integrated Atlantic Ocean Observing System. They also worked together to deliver ocean analysis for the Copernicus Marine Service and are involved in implementing a cloud-based platform, known as the Data Information Access Service (DIAS), to facilitate the use of large volumes of data from the Copernicus portfolio.

The ECMWF's supercomputer facility plays a crucial role in Earth observation and climate modeling by processing large volumes of data from sensors and satellites. It is used to produce and disseminate numerical weather predictions to its Member States. The supercomputer facility is also used to support the development of next-generation models, such as high-resolution digital twins of the Earth. Additionally, the supercomputer is used to analyze and correct for errors in data assimilation, which improves the accuracy of weather and climate predictions.

According to the provided documents, ECMWF's Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS) uses Earth observation data to help with emergency response by providing maps of disaster sites in a semi-automated process, which involves manual analysis of Earth Observation datasets, as well as the use of some AI algorithms. Additionally, CEMS teams provide early warning systems for flood and fire danger.

The Copernicus Observations Workshop is an event organized by ECMWF to address the observation-based content of the Climate Data Store, which is a key part of the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S). The workshop brings together speakers from international agencies and national meteorological services to discuss observation requirements for climate service applications, model evaluation, and reanalysis. The outcomes of the workshop are used to guide the development of the observational component of the Climate Data Store catalogue and to help specify scientific and technical service requirements in this area. This helps to develop Earth observation at ECMWF by ensuring that the Climate Data Store provides reliable and validated information services for environmental and security applications.

ECMWF's research and development activities improve Earth observation and climate science through the development of next-generation models to produce high-resolution digital twins of the Earth, extracting maximum value from observations to produce an accurate analysis of the Earth system, and the development of new products and services such as the Copernicus Climate Change Service and the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service. Additionally, these activities involve collaboration with other organizations to share knowledge, expertise, and resources.

ECMWF uses its supercomputer to support weather forecasting and climate prediction by running numerical weather prediction models, such as the Integrated Forecasting System (IFS). The supercomputer is used to run complex numerical models and analyze large datasets for producing forecasts and reanalyses.
ECMWF's supercomputer facility is located in Italy. ECMWF has its headquarters in the UK and new offices located in Bonn, Germany, as of Summer 2021.

The supercomputer facility at ECMWF is one of the largest of its type in Europe and plays a crucial role in the organization's research and development. It is used for numerical weather predictions, climate modeling, and data analysis. The supercomputer facility is also used to support the development of new products and services, such as the Copernicus Climate Change Service and the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service. Additionally, the supercomputer facility is used to support research in various fields, including climate change, weather forecasting, and oceanography.

ECMWF and Mercator Ocean are partners in many respects, including exchanging scientific information, working on common projects, and progressing together on ocean–atmosphere coupling. They collaborate on data exchange and use, such as ECMWF receiving data from the Copernicus Marine Service like sea-surface temperature, ocean sea ice, and sea-level observations. Additionally, they are working together on the Data Information Access Service (DIAS) project, which aims to provide users with a facility to run their own algorithms "next to the data."

The advantages of using a cloud platform like the Data Information Access Service (DIAS) for handling large data include the ability to efficiently perform analytics and machine learning (AI) on very large volumes of data and information. Additionally, the DIAS platform provides a scalable computing environment, allowing users to build and operate their own services based on Copernicus data and information. This scalability lowers the barriers to entry for companies to build applications and services, making it easier for users to fully take advantage of the wealth of information Copernicus makes available. Furthermore, the DIAS platform offers a single access point to open and free Copernicus data, allowing users to apply processing techniques to develop and promote their own services.
